results.title: The American teacher
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “March of Time”.
Yesterday’s education in the United States was typified by the proverbial Little Red School House and today’s (1947) emphasis is upon the scientific principles of psychology - but all good teachers know that their methods are as individualistic and personal as any other artist’s; all realise the importance of developing in their pupils the ability to think as well as a knowledge of the facts. The film presents the pros and cons of “progressive education” and points out to the American citizen their responsibility for the quality of the education the community provides for its young.

results.title: The American road
results.brief_description: Produced to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Ford Motor Company, this film traces the development of American highways over the last 50 years. It tells the story of man’s method of transportation and how it has influenced his life, business, health and recreation. Includes archival footage of the early days of Henry Ford’s factory, such as the creation of the first assembly line.

results.title: The American revolution
results.brief_description: Portrays highlights of the American Revolution from the Boston Tea Party to the surrender of Cornwallis to Washington at Yorktown. Includes scenes depicting the battles of Lexington and Concord, the attack on Fort Ticonderoga and the campaigns led by General Washington. No other credits available.

results.title: The American revolution
results.creator_credit: Carol Greenwald, Metropolitan Museum of Art and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Western tradition”.
This absorbing series is a survey of 2,000 years of Western civilisation illustrated by paintings, sculpture and other records from the past, compiled by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Historian Eugen Weber looks at the American revolution and how British colonists created a society that tested Enlightenment ideas and resisted restrictions imposed by England.

results.title: The American republic
results.creator_credit: Art Cohen, Metropolitan Museum of Art and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Western tradition”.
This absorbing series is a survey of 2,000 years of Western civilisation illustrated by paintings, sculpture and other records from the past, compiled by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Historian Eugen Weber analyses the American Republic which was comprised of radicals and conservatives and founded on the premises of “Universal Freedoms” for its inhabitants.

results.title: The American parade: we the women
results.brief_description: This factual treatment of the American past balances the unintentional sexism of most US history as now taught. Names like Sarah and Angelina Grimke, Lucretia Mott, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Sojourner Truth, Susan B. Anthony, and Carrie Chapman Catt will now become familiar through vivid, often humorous, sometimes deeply moving historical dramatizations. This film is an introduction to the American women’s movement. Narrated by Mary Tyler Moore. Associate Producer: Lois Bianchi.

results.title: The Amazon: life along the river in Peru
results.brief_description: Following the Amazon River to its sources in the High Andes of Peru, this film surveys the geography of the Maranon river area and the peoples way of life and variation in climate and vegetation on the western and eastern slopes and in the foothills of the Andes. Also shown is the city of Iquitos - the trade centre of the Upper Andes and its environs, the abundantly productive rainforests No other credits available.

results.title: The Amazing newborn
results.creator_credit: Maureen Hack and Patricia E Rambasek
results.brief_description: Shows how normal infants aged 1-7 days can see and have visual preferences, turn their heads in response to spoken words, mimic and move in rhythm to parental voices. It also shows the six states of consciousness first observed by Peter Wolff.
